tinycolors.tprint¶

Attributes¶

Supported

Supported types for prettification. Includes str, list, dict, tuple, set, int, float, bool, and None.

Functions¶

Identifies the starting and ending indices of balanced, non-escaped quotes

prettify_string(→ str)

Highlights syntax, numbers, and quoted strings within a single string.

escape_internal_quotes(→ str)

Escapes double quotes inside a string so it can be wrapped in double quotes.

get_container_color_index(→ int)

Calculates the color index based on the nesting level for bracket coloring.

prettify_simple(→ str)

Highlights simple types (bool, None, int, float) with their respective colors.

prettify_container(→ str)

Generic function to handle lists, tuples, and sets, controlling

prettify_list(→ str)

Recursively converts a list into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

prettify_dict(→ str)

Recursively converts a dict into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

prettify_tuple(→ str)

NEW: Recursively converts a tuple into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

prettify_set(→ str)

NEW: Recursively converts a set into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

The main entry point for prettifying an element, dispatching to the

tprint(→ None)

Prints the prettified element to the console.

Module Contents¶

tinycolors.tprint.Supported[source]¶

Supported types for prettification. Includes str, list, dict, tuple, set, int, float, bool, and None.

tinycolors.tprint.is_quote(char: str) → bool[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.is_bracket(char: str) → bool[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.is_opening_bracket(char: str) → bool[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.is_closing_bracket(char: str) → bool[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.get_bracket_type(char: str) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.get_bracket_colors()[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.color_bracket(char: str, bracket_stack: list[tuple[str, int]]) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.open_quote(char: str) → tuple[bool, str, str][source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.close_quote(substring: str) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.append_char(substring: str, char: str) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.color_syntax(text: str) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.color_numbers(text: str) → str[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.handle_escape(char: str, escaped: bool) → tuple[str, bool][source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.start_quote(char: str) → tuple[bool, str, str][source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.maybe_close_quote(substring: str, char: str, quote_char: str, next_char: str) → tuple[bool, str, str | None][source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.append_result(result_parts: list[str], substring: str, in_quote: bool)[source]¶
tinycolors.tprint.find_closed_quotes(element: str) → tuple[set[int], set[int]][source]¶

Identifies the starting and ending indices of balanced, non-escaped quotes in a string, handling escaped internal quotes like ‘”’.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_string(element: str) → str[source]¶

Highlights syntax, numbers, and quoted strings within a single string. Also handles bracket color matching when outside of quotes.

tinycolors.tprint.escape_internal_quotes(s: str) → str[source]¶

Escapes double quotes inside a string so it can be wrapped in double quotes.

tinycolors.tprint.get_container_color_index(level: int) → int[source]¶

Calculates the color index based on the nesting level for bracket coloring.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_simple(element: Any) → str[source]¶

Highlights simple types (bool, None, int, float) with their respective colors.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_container(element: Any, open_char: str, close_char: str, level: int, is_key_value: bool = False) → str[source]¶

Generic function to handle lists, tuples, and sets, controlling the bracket type and key/value formatting.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_list(element: list[Any], level: int = 0) → str[source]¶

Recursively converts a list into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_dict(element: dict[Any, Any], level: int = 0) → str[source]¶

Recursively converts a dict into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_tuple(element: tuple[Any, Ellipsis], level: int = 0) → str[source]¶

NEW: Recursively converts a tuple into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify_set(element: set[Any], level: int = 0) → str[source]¶

NEW: Recursively converts a set into a color-highlighted, formatted string.

tinycolors.tprint.prettify(element: Supported, level: int = 1) → str[source]¶

The main entry point for prettifying an element, dispatching to the appropriate formatting function based on type.

tinycolors.tprint.tprint(element: Supported, level: int = 0) → None[source]¶

Prints the prettified element to the console.

tinycolors.tprint.demo()[source]¶

Demonstrates the features of the prettify module, including the new support for tuples and sets.
